Pull Requests (PRs) are the heart of **collaborative development**.

| **Knowledge Sharing** | Team learns from each other |

# Code Reviews ğŸ‘€

Code review is the process of examining code changes for quality.

## Why Review Code?

- ğŸ› **Catch Bugs** - Find issues before production
- ğŸ“š **Share Knowledge** - Learn from each other
- ğŸ¨ **Maintain Standards** - Consistent code style
- ğŸ”’ **Security** - Identify vulnerabilities
- ğŸ“ **Documentation** - Understand the codebase

## What to Look For

| Category | Check |
|----------|-------|
| **Logic** | Does it work correctly? |
| **Design** | Is it well-structured? |
| **Style** | Follows conventions? |
| **Tests** | Adequate coverage? |
| **Security** | Any vulnerabilities? |
| **Performance** | Any bottlenecks? |
| **Documentation** | Is it clear? |

## Review Checklist

```
âœ… Code compiles and runs
âœ… Tests pass and cover new code
âœ… No obvious bugs or edge cases missed
âœ… Variables and functions well-named
âœ… No hardcoded values that should be config
âœ… Error handling is appropriate
âœ… No security issues
âœ… Performance is acceptable
```

> ğŸ¯ **Remember:** Review the code, not the person!

slides.title: Giving Good Feedback
slides.content:
# Giving Effective Feedback ğŸ’¬

## The Art of Constructive Criticism

### âœ… Good Feedback

```
"Consider extracting this logic into a separate function 
for better reusability and testability."

"This could cause a null pointer exception if user is 
undefined. Maybe add a null check?"

"Nice solution! One small improvement: we could use 
Array.filter() here for cleaner code."
```

### âŒ Bad Feedback

```
"This is wrong."
"Why did you do it this way?"
"I would never write code like this."
```

## Comment Types

| Prefix | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| **nit:** | Minor issue, optional fix |
| **suggestion:** | Improvement idea |
| **question:** | Need clarification |
| **blocking:** | Must fix before merge |
| **praise:** | Something done well! |

## Tone Guidelines

- ğŸ¤ Be **respectful** and **kind**
- â“ Ask questions instead of making demands
- ğŸ’¡ Offer solutions, not just criticism
- ğŸŒŸ Acknowledge good work
- ğŸ¯ Be **specific** and **actionable**

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Assume positive intent from the author!

# Inline Comments ğŸ“

Comment directly on specific lines of code.

## Types of Inline Comments

### Single-Line Comment

### Multi-Line Comment

### Suggestion Mode (GitHub)

```markdown
```suggestion

```
```

Author can apply with one click!

## Best Practices for Inline Comments

### 1. Be Specific
```
âŒ "Fix this"
âœ… "This loop could be simplified using Array.map()"
```

### 2. Provide Context
```
âŒ "Change this variable name"
âœ… "Consider renaming 'd' to 'data' for clarity, 
    as per our naming conventions"
```

### 3. Link Resources
```

See: https://docs.example.com/debounce"
```

### 4. Distinguish Severity
```
"nit: Extra whitespace here"
"blocking: This will throw an exception on null input"
```

> ğŸ¯ **Tip:** Keep comments focused and actionable!

slides.title: Branch Naming
slides.content:
# Branch Naming Conventions ğŸ“›

## Common Patterns

```
<type>/<issue-id>-<description>
```

## Branch Types

| Prefix | Purpose | Example |
|--------|---------|--------|
| `feature/` | New feature | `feature/PROJ-123-user-login` |
| `bugfix/` | Bug fix | `bugfix/PROJ-456-fix-crash` |
| `hotfix/` | Urgent fix | `hotfix/security-patch` |
| `release/` | Release prep | `release/v2.0.0` |
| `docs/` | Documentation | `docs/api-reference` |
| `refactor/` | Code refactor | `refactor/cleanup-utils` |
| `test/` | Tests only | `test/add-unit-tests` |

## Good Naming Examples

```bash
# Feature branch
git checkout -b feature/PROJ-123-add-oauth-login

# Bug fix with issue reference
git checkout -b bugfix/PROJ-456-fix-null-pointer

# Quick hotfix
git checkout -b hotfix/CVE-2024-1234-patch

# Documentation update
git checkout -b docs/update-readme
```

## Rules

- âœ… Use **lowercase**
- âœ… Use **hyphens** as separators
- âœ… Include **issue ID** when applicable
- âœ… Keep it **descriptive** but **short**
- âŒ Avoid special characters
- âŒ No spaces

> ğŸ¯ **Tip:** Consistent naming makes branches easy to find!

# Resolving Merge Conflicts âš”ï¸

Conflicts occur when the same lines are modified in different branches.

## Conflict Markers

```javascript
function greet(name) {
<<<<<<< HEAD
    return `Hello, ${name}!`;
=======
    return `Hi there, ${name}!`;
>>>>>>> feature-branch
}
```

## Resolution Steps

### 1. Identify Conflicts
```bash
git status
# Shows files with conflicts
```

### 2. Open Conflicted Files
- Find conflict markers
- Decide which version to keep
- Or combine both changes

### 3. Resolve and Commit
```bash
# After editing files
git add .
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflicts"
```

## Prevention Tips

- ğŸ“ Keep PRs small and focused
- ğŸ”„ Sync with main branch frequently
- ğŸ“¢ Communicate about shared files
- ğŸƒ Review and merge PRs quickly

# Draft Pull Requests ğŸ“

Draft PRs indicate **work in progress**.
